Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs

(2) Summary

APIs are becoming increasingly important at the business level, because they are an essential ingredient of Digital Transformation. The growing importance of APIs highlights the increasing digitalization of businesses and our society and economy in general. But it also creates new challenges how to best surface and manage these inherently technical artifacts for a variety of users. APIs have matured from connectivity that only matters on a very technical level to capabilities that can drive enormous amounts of value (just think of Stripe or Twilio). The API community moved from gateways as a way to address general technical concerns, to portals for improving developers experience (DX) and making APIs easier to find and use, to platforms which address the increasing decentralization and heterogeneity of today's IT landscape. This presentation discusses this development, the driving factors, and what you can learn from it for the future of APIs.

A Brief History of API Management

A Brief History of API Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs

(7) A Brief History of APIs

  • APIs for interconnecting programs have been around since the 1950s
    • Reuse in programming needs APIs (libraries)
    • Every operating system needs APIs (system libraries)
  • APIs for interconnecting computers have been around since the 1960s
    • Network APIs were called communication protocols for most of history
    • Computer networks make no sense without communication protocols
  • The 1990s saw the rise of the Internet and the Web
    • B2B interconnections existed but weren't designed/meant to scale
    • 2000 saw the first companies launching their APIs (Salesforce, eBay, [https://blog.postman.com/intro-to-apis-history-of-apis/]…)


A Brief History of API Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs

(8) APIs as Intra-Organizational Interfaces

  • Move from building systems to evolving ecosystems
    • Decreases coupling and increases delivery velocity
  • APIs become the only way how teams communicate
    • Findable, managed, and documented APIs as digital building blocks


A Brief History of API Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs

(9) APIs as Inter-Organizational Interfaces

  • APIs as a new approach for B2B
    • Reusable and standards-based interfaces for collaboration
  • New ways of creating value chains in the API economy
    • Some companies directly monetize their APIs
    • Many companies create value by building API-based value chains
  • New business models in the platform economy
    • Platforms build on value co-creation models

(11) API Growth needs Management



API Gateways: Managing Technology Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs

(12) Application-Level Security with API Gateways

  • No more implied trust between API providers and consumers
  • Management and visibility for each individual API
  • Convenience functions such as format conversions


API Gateways: Managing Technology Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs

(13) API Gateways: Productized Management



API Gateways: Managing Technology Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs

(14) The API Value Proposition

  • APIs successfully unlock and drive business value
  • APIs help with decoupling development teams
    • Private APIs decrease team coupling and coordination overhead
    • Partner APIs make it easier to co-create value with partners
    • Public APIs outsource innovation and create visibility and growth
  • ⇒ Decouple API technology and API value

(16) API Portals: Turn APIs into Products



API Portals: Focus on Users Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs

(17) Growth → Diversity

  • API become the connective fabric of digital transformation
    • Digital transformation is much more than using APIs
    • Digital transformation is impossible without using APIs
  • Momentum and growth mean more APIs across the organization
    • API governance can help with providing guidance and guardrails
    • Deployment diversity happens on a level lower than APIs
  • Cloud, multi-cloud, and hybrid deployments become the norm
    • Limiting IT to one environment is not feasible anymore
    • IT practices must evolve alongside the increasing diversity


API Portals: Focus on Users Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs

(18) API Gateway Sprawl



API Portals: Focus on Users Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs

(19) Gateways & Portals

  • Most portals were provided by gateway vendors
  • Portals mostly conceived inside-out and not outside-in


API Portals: Focus on Users Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs

(23) Collect Digital Building Blocks

  • Many gateways are provided by infrastructure/solution vendors
  • APIs should be visible regardless of how/where they are provided
    • This is one of the main value propositions of APIs
  • Provide a unifying catalog on top of the technical gateways


API Catalogs: Focus on Value Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs

(28) API Value is in API Consumption

  • API management has grown into digital building block management
  • Technical management and business-oriented management should be decoupled
  • Catalogs provide an abstraction on top of gateways
  • Portals should be built on catalogs instead of gateways


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): API Management for Grown-Ups: From Gateways to Portals to Catalogs
